tasks: As an Explorer, you should create a simple collaboration template using Google Docs or Trello to help facilitate team discussions. Document your process and share the template with me for feedback.

Write a short reflection (150-200 words) on how you currently communicate design decisions to your team. Identify areas where you'd like to improve and what strategies you can implement in the coming weeks.
Conduct 2 minutes of self-reflection on your current collaboration style. What are your strengths and weaknesses? How do you think this will impact your future projects?

Create a basic product thinking framework using sticky notes or a mind mapping tool. Identify 3 pain points in the design process that you'd like to address. Document your thoughts and share with me for feedback.
Develop a simple user research plan for a hypothetical project. Outline the methods you would use to gather data, analyze results, and present findings. Share your plan with me.

Design an aesthetic-usable effect using Adobe XD or Sketch. Create a simple design element (e.g., button, icon) that incorporates Jakob's Law. Document your process and share the final result with me for feedback.
Write a short essay (250-300 words) on Miller’s Law and its application in UX design. Explain how understanding this law can improve user experience.

Conduct a usability test using the 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design. Choose a simple website or app and evaluate it against these guidelines. Document your findings and share with me.

Create a comprehensive product thinking and strategy document outlining how you would approach a hypothetical project. Include a clear problem statement, user research findings, design decisions, and a plan for implementation.

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, you have the power to shape the user experience and create products that delight and inspire. To unlock your full potential, focus on building a strong foundation in UX fundamentals, UI craft, and collaboration - with every project, ask yourself how you can use research, strategy, and design to drive meaningful change.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Usability Heuristics
topics.summary: Applying usability heuristics will help you identify and address pain points in user interfaces, improving overall UX.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing products using the 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design and document findings on how well they adhere to each principle
Create a new wireframe that incorporates at least 5 of the usability heuristics, focusing on user flow and error prevention

topics.name: Aesthetic-Usability Effect
topics.summary: Understanding the Aesthetic-Usability Effect will help you create visually appealing interfaces that also prioritize usability.
practice_points: Design 2 mockups of a product's login page, one with an aesthetically pleasing design and one with a more utilitarian approach, and document your thought process

topics.name: Conducting User Interviews
topics.summary: Gaining user insights through interviews will help you validate design decisions and identify areas for improvement.
practice_points: Conduct 2 user interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework, taking detailed notes on users' goals and pain points
